name: Whitelist by IP Address in Microsoft Exchange 2016 and 2019
title: Whitelist by IP Address in Microsoft Exchange 2016 and 2019
body:
Note:As of April 2023, Microsoft no longer supports Exchange 2013. For more information, see the Exchange 2013 end of support roadmap article from Microsoft.

In this article, you’ll learn how to whitelist our Phishing Security Tests (PSTs) and training emails in your Exchange 2016 and 2019 mail server. Whitelisting our IP addresses allows us to bypass your Microsoft Exchange Online Protection (EOP) mail filter and ensure the deliverability of our PSTs and training notifications.

Important:Some whitelisting configurations may not be available in environments outside of the US.

To learn how to whitelist by IP address, follow the steps below.

  1. Log in to your Exchange Admin Center
  2. Navigate to Mail flow > Rules.
  3. Click Add a rule > Create a new rule.
  4. Give the rule a name, such as "Bypass Spam Filtering by IP Address".
  5. In the Apply this rule if... fields, select The sender and IP address is in any of these ranges or exactly matches.
  6. In the specify IP address ranges pop-up window, enter all of our IP addresses. After each IP address, click Add. For a list of our IP addresses, see our Whitelisting Guide. 
  7. After you've entered all the IP address, click Save.
  8. In the Do the following fields, select Modify the message properties and set a message header.
  9. Click the Enter text on the left and enter "X-MS-Exchange-Organization-BypassClutter". This field is case-sensitive.
  10. Click Save.
  11. Click the second Enter text and enter "true". This field is case-sensitive.
  12. Click Save.
  13. To the right of the Do the following fields, click the plus icon.
  14. In the And fields, select Modify the message properties and set the spam confidence level (SCL).
  15. In the specify SCL pop-up window, select Bypass spam filtering. Then, click Save.
  16. Click Next.
  17. On the Set rule settings page, click Next. As a best practice, we recommend leaving the other options at their default settings.
  18. On the Review and finish page, click Finish.
Tip: To ensure that you have whitelisted correctly, see our How to Verify You Have Whitelisted KnowBe4 Correctly article.

This image depicts a configuration form for defining a custom filtering rule, organized into conditional and action blocks, typical of email transport or security settings.

**Rule Structure:**

1.  **Name:**
    *   **Label:** `Name *` (Required field).
    *   **Value:** `Bypass Spam Filtering by IP Address`.

2.  **Apply this rule if * (Condition Block):**
    *   **Label:** `Apply this rule if *` (Required block).
    *   **UI Element 1 (Condition Definition):** A nested set of dropdown menus defining the condition logic. The initial condition reads: `The sender` [Dropdown] `IP address is in any of these ranges or ...` [Dropdown].
    *   **Condition Detail:** A line specifying the target of the rule: `Sender's IP address is in the range`.
    *   **Input Field/Link:** `Enter words` (editable placeholder/link).
    *   **Controls:** A plus icon (`+`) for adding a new clause, and a pencil icon (edit) next to the IP address range input.

3.  **Do the following * (Action Block):**
    *   **Label:** `Do the following *` (Required block).
    *   **UI Element:** Two adjacent dropdown fields, both with the placeholder `Select one`.
    *   **Control:** A plus icon (`+`) for adding additional actions.

4.  **Except if (Exclusion Block):**
    *   **Label:** `Except if` (Optional exclusion block).
    *   **UI Element:** Two adjacent dropdown fields, both with the placeholder `Select one`.
    *   **Controls:** A plus icon (`+`) for adding another exception, and a trashcan/delete icon for removing the row.

This image displays a **"Set rule conditions"** configuration screen, likely from an administrative UI for email transport rules (e.g., Exchange Admin Center).

**Structure and Content:**

1.  **Title and Description:** The page title is "**Set rule conditions**." A subtitle reads: "Name and set conditions for your transport rule."
2.  **Name Section (Completed):**
    *   Label: **Name \***
    *   Input Field Content: `Bypass Spam Filtering by IP Address`
3.  **Apply this rule if (Condition Section - Completed):**
    *   Label: **Apply this rule if \***
    *   Two interconnected dropdown menus define the condition:
        *   Dropdown 1 (Trigger): `The sender` (selected)
        *   Dropdown 2 (Criteria): `IP address is in any of these ranges or ...` (selected)
    *   Defined Condition Text: `Sender's IP address is in the range '147.160.167.0/26' or '23.21.109.197' or '23.21.109.212'`
    *   Control Icons: A **Plus (+) icon** (to add more conditions) and a **Pencil icon** (to edit the existing condition) are visible next to the condition line.
4.  **Do the following (Action Section - Completed):**
    *   Label: **Do the following \***
    *   Two interconnected dropdown menus define the action:
        *   Dropdown 1 (Action Type): `Modify the message properties` (selected)
        *   Dropdown 2 (Specific Action): `set a message header` (selected)
    *   Defined Action Text: `Set the message header 'X-MS-Exchange-Organization-BypassClutter' to the value 'true'`
    *   Control Icons: A **Plus (+) icon** (to add more actions) and a **Pencil icon** are visible. (Note: A large orange arrow points to the Plus icon in this section.)
5.  **Except if (Exception Section - Empty):**

    *   Control Icons: A **Plus (+) icon** and a **Trash icon** (to delete an existing exception) are visible.
6.  **Navigation:** A dark blue button at the bottom reads "**Next**."
